qas.question: Why was the Somerset county Canal built

answers.text: to reduce the cost of transportation of coal and other heavy produce

qas.question: What was in use along the canal

answers.text: A planned 11.7 km (7.3 mi) branch to Midford was never built

qas.question: What was laid on the path to Midford

answers.text: in 1815 a tramway was laid along its towing path
In 1871 the tramway was purchased by the Somerset and Dorset Joint Railway (S&DJR), and operated until the 1950s

qas.question: Who built the Somerset Coal Canal?
In what year had it been planned to build a branch to Midford?
In what year were the several tramways completed?
In what year was Paulton established?

context: The Somerset Coal Canal was built in the early 19th century <a0_0>to reduce the cost of transportation of coal and other heavy produce<a0_0/>. The first 16 kilometres (10 mi), running from a junction with the Kennet and Avon Canal, along the Cam valley, to a terminal basin at Paulton, were in use by <b6_0><b8_0>1805<b8_0/><b6_0/>, together with <a1_0>several tramways<a1_0/>. <a2_0>A planned 11.7 km (7.3 mi) branch to Midford was never built<a2_0/>, but <a3_0>in 1815 a tramway was laid along its towing path<a3_0/>. <a4_0>In <b7_0>1871<b7_0/> the tramway was purchased by the <b5_0>Somerset and Dorset Joint Railway<b5_0/> (S&DJR), and operated until the 1950s<a4_0/>.
